hints.content: Consider how the order of cooking dishes affects the like-time coefficient. The time taken to cook each dish is cumulative, so cooking higher satisfaction dishes later can yield a higher total.
Notice that if a dish has a negative satisfaction level, it may reduce the overall like-time coefficient. Think about whether you should include such dishes.
Sorting the satisfaction levels can help. If you sort the array in ascending order, you can evaluate the impact of including or excluding dishes more easily.
After sorting, consider starting from the highest satisfaction dish and working backwards to see if including lower satisfaction dishes increases the total.
What happens if you only include dishes with positive satisfaction values? Explore the case where you might want to discard all negative values.
You may want to calculate the like-time coefficient incrementally. Start with an empty total and add dishes one by one, checking the resulting total each time.
Think about the cumulative nature of the time variable. Each dish contributes to the total time, so the position of each dish in the cooking order matters significantly.
Create a function that calculates the total like-time coefficient for a given set of dishes. This will help you test different combinations of included dishes.
Consider using a greedy approach. Start with the highest satisfaction dish and keep adding dishes as long as they increase the total like-time coefficient.
What if you reached a point where adding a dish decreases the total? You should stop adding dishes at that point.
Remember that you can discard dishes. If the satisfaction level of a dish is low enough, it may be beneficial to skip it entirely.
Think about edge cases, such as when all satisfaction levels are negative. In such cases, the maximum like-time coefficient would be zero since no dishes should be cooked.
As you implement your solution, be mindful of the constraints. The maximum length of the satisfaction array is 500, so ensure your approach is efficient.
Consider the impact of the order of dishes after sorting. If you start from the least satisfying dish and move to the most, you may find a point where the total starts to decrease.
To summarize, you want to maximize the sum of the like-time coefficients by carefully selecting which dishes to cook based on their satisfaction levels and the order of cooking.

questionNotes: Dishes can be prepared in any order, and some dishes can be discarded.
The like-time coefficient is defined as time[i] * satisfaction[i].
If all satisfaction levels are negative, the output should be 0.
